reviews.review_msg: Jacqueline Nelsen is an okay lecturer. Her quizzes are unfair and her assignments are dry and uninteresting. She teaches you what you need to know but you probably won't enjoy the process. I'd recommend taking CMPT105W with a different prof if you can, and leaving extra time in your schedule for essay work if you can't. No final exam for the course

Where to start? Nelsen is horrible in every way possible. She treats university students like high school kids, routinely yelling at people in class because they were 5 minutes late. Throws tantrums. Docks marks unnecessarily. Changed assignment requirements after due dates. Overreaches while she is a lousy teacher unqualified for her position.

This has nothing to do with writing skills. It's mostly on social issues related to female inequality in stem. My female friend went to her office hours, and Nelsen told her not to worry about her grade, as she gives A's to female students.
Nelsen has no idea in computer sciences. Also her grammar is bad, and she makes A LOT of spelling mistakes.

- Mandatory lectures 
- High work load 
- Two 48 hour essays over the weekend 
- A ton of quizzes at the beginning of the semester
- Nothing is related to technical writing 
- Feels like an English and Social Justice bootcamp 
- Everything is micromanaged 
- Changes grading criteria after assignments are due 
- Constantly contradicts herself
AVOID
Jacquie is one of the worst profs at SFU. She isn't qualified to teach CMPT courses, especially upper-div ones.
This course with Nelsen is basically Social Justice Warrior boot camp masquerading as Technical Writing
Course content is does nothing to prepare you for actual technical writing. Feels like I am redoing Grade 11 English.
All of the aforementioned 1 star reviews are accurate.

She doesn't understand her own material, frequently gives contradicting instructions, most of the assignments are redundant. The final paper for this class was split into 3 parts except every part was essentially the same thing.

This might be the worst class I've ever taken, and that's saying a lot. Every singly assignment is completely micromanaged with 3 page tables that detail everything there could possibly be. 
Instructions are inconsistent. 
Lectures are incredibly boring. 
Sometimes has mandatory in-class activities so you still have to show up.

Thanks to her, this course takes up double time than an usual CS course does. I have to say that every single day for a third year CS student is important. But she is able to waste your valuable time on those numerous and useless quizs and assignment. Should she make none decisions that make you happy, don't be suprise because this is typically her

To conclude, this course by Nelsen is heavy-loaded. You will not only expect 80-100 small quizzes and assignments but also two intensive 48-hour projects, which stress you out. (And also an individual essay) Very very limited knowledge you can gain from this course.I won't expect any potential SDE would want to spend such an amount of time on this.

Too many boring quizzes. I guess they are only 5% in the final grade. I ever spent more than 6 hours working on 14 quizzes on weekends. Too many group assignments and individual assignments, asking about teamwork again and over again. It's definitely the worst professor I met at SFU.

Jacquie genuinely cares about her students. She has a lot of experience as a lecturer and an engineer and loves to share her experiences with her class. The information she presents is actually useful and can be easily applied. She does assign a lot of homework and isn't lenient about extensions or anything. Her papers are hard but doable

Take if you want an easy pass but annoying class. She relies to heavily on the textbook and rote memorization, rather than actually teaching students useful writing skills through consistent practice. There are many tedious and pointless quizzes/participation work that will make you hate school. 2nd worst class I took at SFU.

She is a genuinely kind person. She didnt give to much schoolwork and was always available to help and was understanding. That said the major drawbacks were her quizzes that were based on her slides and the textbook and were essentially just memorization. And her TAs were kind of mean. But she rounded my high A- to an A and I didnt even ask.

At the beginning of the term, there's 20 or so quizzes which is basically reading comprehension. After that, small stuff like participation (by attending via sign up sheet) and peer reviews account for your mark. No final, only two papers worth a majority of your mark. Four quizzes, with content pulled from lectures, which is from the textbook. EZ

Definitely not as bad as her score would suggest. Her lectures are really boring but necessary as questions for quizzes are pulled straight from her presentations. Lots of short assignments/quizzes on Canvas. Wrote two short essays for the course. Textbook is not necessary. Pretty easy course if you know how to write and read the rubrics correctly.

Dr. Nelsen really cares about her students and puts lots of effort into making lectures as engaging as possible (many in-class activities). She is very open to feedback about the course and communicates frequently to make sure everyone is kept up to date. There are many assignments (do not take very long), but she marks fairly and quickly.

Professor Nelsen is really nice and genuinely cares about her students, she is very approachable. However, I hate her teaching. Quizzes sucked, no feedback was given and I was unsure what they wanted. Rubrics were very vague and left many of us unsure of what to do for assignments. Comments were only occasionally left on graded material.
Easy materials but lots of assignments.
Need to pay a lot of effort for a high score, but once you paid, then can receive an ideal grade.
She is ok... She is one of the few instructors who really care about the students.
Worst prof ever... Useless course.

After seeing Dr. Nelsen's ratings before taking CMPT105 W I definitely was not looking forward to this class. However, Nelsen cared for her students and was a decent teacher. I barely studied for this class and still did well. Also didn't need to read the textbook at all, just go over the powerpoint slides before quizzes. No final, only 2 essays.

Jacqueline Neslen really doesn't deserve all these bad reviews. Sure, the class was pretty pointless but she obviously does really care about her students. The quizzes in her class all memorization of very specific class details, however they really aren't hard if you just pay attention to every lecture. Seriously pretty good and caring prof.

the quizzes are kinda bad lol - you'd assume you'd get graded more on WRITING than MEMORIZATION in a legit WRITING course but nooooo. 20% of your grade is based on pure memory and luck lmfao. also she's very against feedback/suggestions/criticism, like she just refuses to change anything despite giving us this giant feedback survey???? like ok lmao

She's really not that bad. It's a lot of quizzes in the first week or so but then you only have a few bigger projects like essays. Plus there's only 4 quizzes, no final or midterms. The quizzes can be tough with questions that definitely require you to read the textbook, but you can get an ok grade on those and just go hard on the papers. She cares

I literally cannot believe this is an accredited course. We had to write: -How to get more women in stem -One social issues vaguely related to CS. -Describing an Oreo and legos. Course was taught at a grade 10-11 level, with persuasive writing as the focus, and you get spammed constant assignments. This is the lowest SFU has ever been.

Unlike other classes that make you buy a textbook, this class forces you to buy legos. At least smashing your head with a textbook would give you a concussion that would hopefully let you forget about the terrible experiences of this class...

The class was disorganized and overwhelming at times, but given the circumstances at the time, I can understand why. Jacquie cares a lot and she gives really good feedback when you go to office hour (go, it's helpful). The class was not easy, but if you put the effort in, you'll do great. Read the textbook thoroughly. Tests were tough & specific.

Dr. Nelsen knows her stuff. Yes, this is a CMPT course, but it is primarily a writing and research course. Dr. Nelsen makes use of Canvas liberally and adds many assignments and quizzes. Most are quick to do, so don't be put off by this. Do the library quizzes right away and make use of what you learn, like Zotero for references; a real time saver!

Dr. Nelsen was a wonderful prof for this course as she seemed extremely passionate of the content. I warn that this course is philosophy and writing (i.e., no coding) but if you like the prior then you'll definitely enjoy the course. Give Dr. Nelsen a chance and don't rely on the RMP echo chamber, she's awesome and gives good grades!

The workload is ridiculously heavy and completely irrelevant to technical writing in CS. Take this class with Pearce/Milan for a higher grade and 10x less work. She also gets very defensive anytime someone brings up a concern or suggestion. She improved slightly throughout the semester, but still wasn't great.

- Says she would check zoom logs for attendance, but does not - Says she would check canvas logs to prevent cheating during tests, but does not - Loo-ng and typo-filled requirements for assignments - Spams your email (sometimes multiple times for one thing) throughout the term - Terrible workload that surpasses most if not all of my CMPT courses.
Probably one of the worst pieces of content I have ever had for this excuse of a "course." Did I learn anything? No. Is the format conducive to learning? No. Avoid her like the plague.

Went to office hours to appeal my grade. She didn't even read my paper. Just found a random typo and said I should proof-read next time because it leaves bad impression. I said she has lots of typos in her assignments and emails, and she became defensive, and said English is not my mother tongue, so I don't know. I grew up in Burnaby since I was 3

After hearing all the bad reviews, 105W this semester (Spring 2021) was not as bad as I was expecting. You can easily get a good grade on the essays if you follow the rubric, and the quizzes are fair if you studied. Jacquie is mindful that we're in a pandemic, and offers good advice during office hours.

Yes, this course can be disorganized and a lot of her content looks copied from 105. Yes, you will do the work of two classes. Yes, this class did not closely follow the outline for the course. However, it's not difficult content and she was tasked with creating a new curriculum during a global trauma. She teaches well and cares. Figure it out.

Jacqueline is great. This course can be pretty dry, but she tries to get through the material and made sure we got it. The essay grading criteria is really clear, and if you follow the course structure (do the essay outline, peer review, write final draft), you'll do fine.

The TAs seem to be choosing random student's outlines and essays to criticize and give them low grades. Quizzes seem to require a good memory as compared to a good understanding of the material. Overall, one of the worst classes that I have taken.

The WORST prof ever! The positive reviews for her, she probably wrote herself from fake accounts. Material she teaches is completely unrelated to syllabus or to CS. Her 376W is mostly the same course as 105W because she doesn't know what to teach. Ignores students needs. I'm from Asia, had to stay up until 2am for mandatory attendance. SFU FIRE HER

I have learned many valuable research skills in this course, which can help me start my graduate study later this year. Although someone argues that the teaching materials are not CS-related, people should understand that this is a writing course. Writing is a transferrable skill. I recommend people who want to continue graduate study take this.

Jacquie's 376W is a complete waste of time! For a computer science technical writing course, course material and assignments certainly feel like an ESL class at times! Even though the course is a disgrace to the faculty and students, do yourself a favour and take this course with anyone other than Jacquie!

Want 11 quizzes in one day? Want 70 assignments/quizzes (not joking) by the end of the term including 2, 48-hour weekend group projects that are meaningless? Does not teach the curriculum stated in the outline. Often does not answer questions properly because she gets defensive and won't actually read what you're asking. Horrendous prof, avoid!!!

Extremely disorganized class, with material copy-pasted from CMPT 105W. Only half of the material that is copy-pasted is double-checked, so instructions become unclear, with conflicting word counts for the same assignment. If you miss the word count, you get 0. She says she doesn't scale. Uses TA's outside of the faculty.

This class isn't really a gpa booster, it required more work than I anticipated. Got above average in most of the essays/tests and final grade got scaled in my favour. First years couldn't handle this course and constantly complained about every little mistake. It was a bit unorganized but the profs rough drafts/essays helped improve my writing.

Class average ended up as a B+ when I took this course in Fall 2020. The course isn't extremely difficult, however the reasons why you lose marks in the first place are infuriating and non-sensical. Read the other posts as they are completely valid complaints.

My writing abilities have gone down since taking this class. She constantly contradicts herself about what good writing is. I went to her office hours asking for help, shed tell me what to write then the day after would call the part she told me to write is garbage. Her exams are not related to studying its just pure luck on what you will get.

The prof expects you to memorize almost every little detail of your textbook, and every detail and spoken word from her. On the final, one question was What is my favorite video of all time? She lacks transparency in her rubrics and cant tell you everything shes grading you on.

She is very textboo0k heavy. She doesn't give many details. On the Final for Fall 2020 she asked "What was the instructor's favourite video". I did not know we had to study personal details about her. She also does not know a thing about computer science and teaches us ENGINEERING material. She does not give relevant information at all.

We never had projects based on the material. We had two essays where she had us peer review after we submitted rendering the feedback useless. She graded outlines two days before the essays were due making the feedback useless. The final had questions about her and required memorization not comprehension. This class should not be this hard to pass.

Pros: Tries to be relatable and uplifting Cons: Everything else lol, tests you on personal information (her dog's names, favourite youtube video, etc), tests/quizes are extremely difficult because you're required to memorize specific examples shown/said in class + specific lines from the textbook. You don't know which ones, so memorize it all lol

The course was disorganized since some rubrics for essays were copypasted and not elaborated on. Tests are very difficult, unrewarding those who studied course material (e.g. questions such as: "what is the instructor's favourite video" may appear on a test) requiring inane amount of memorization. A link between TAs and the prof. didn't exist.

pros about this prof: she is energetic, and she tries to relate with her students and be more interesting. The downsides are that she is very disorganized, and her tests are extremely difficult due to the need to memorize an entire textbook and items mentioned in lectures. Assignment criteria was all over the place and often not clear.

Fall 2020 CMPT105W with Nelsen was am an absolute nightmare. Unrealistic expectations from students, and probably one of the worst final exams ever made. 35 mins to do a 50 MC question exam with no ability to review questions. Do not take this class with her.
Final exam for Fall 2020 was absolutely scuffed. If you want to do well in this class, be prepared to literally absorb the textbook into your brain.

Try to avoid registering for a class taught by Jacqueline. Her cmpt 105w is a very heavy class with a ton of textbook readings, assignments, and pointless peer views. The peer review for the first essay was done after we submitted it so the feedback was useless. The second peer review our feedback was locked on canvas so we again did it for nothing

Imagine being a computing science student, taking quizzes and midterms with questions like: "as an engineer, what is the most important..." and memorizing numerous engineering-exclusive concepts. Imagine reading an entire textbook that constantly preaches how important the textbook is to ENGINEERS, while full of engineering jargon. I DON'T CARE.

Prof doesn't let people go back on quizzes or final, 35 min final, less time than our midterm and she didn't even tell us the format until very late and kept flip flopping about what the final is. Avoid this prof. Terrible prof.

+cheerful mood, organized course page -heavily textbook reliant if you want to pass the course(tests and exams) participation counts for marks as well, extra marks for students who participate a lot in the discussion pages tries to ensure you're always up-to-date(check your email!)

This class is truly horrible. The class requires you to read a textbook and memorize it completely. question on the midterm, final and quizzes include questions like, "What page is table 2.3b on?" and "What page are the rhetorical pattern methods talked about?". Be prepared to memorize the whole textbook if you want to get a good mark.

A miracle that she has a PhD, the level of grammar in her emails are that of an ESL student. Teaches straight out of an engineering textbook for comp sci students. The other reviews will tell you just how bad her quizzes and midterms are. Just don't take this prof. Completely incompetent.

Does multiple-choice quizzes except the questions are about absurdly specific details in the textbook. It's a very poor way to test knowledge and it seems as though there's no way to properly prepare unless you memorize every word in the textbook.

No need to scroll any further, I'll make it simple for you. If you don't have to take this prof, don't. If you do have to take a course with this prof, I wish you the best of luck, prepare for anything and everything.

I like her as a person but that does not change the fact that she's simply a bad professor. The midterm and quizzes are multiple-choice and test for memorization, not ability. Essays are graded harshly but not unreasonable. Read the other reviews. Not much more I can say except she is really really bad.
Assigns peer reviews after essays are due and does not allow the newly received feedback to be used. Also read all the other reviews.

the content she teaches is completely useless. why am i being forced to memorize an entire textbook that has no correlation to comp sci. essays are marked harshly and the quizzes are not fair. expect to memorize literally every single sentence of a 350 pg textbook when u take this course. as a person shes chill but this isnt rate my person

Horribly unfair teacher. Suspected kids of cheating on quizzes, and so she decided to no longer allow reviewing questions on Canvas, and reduced quiz times from 10 mins to 7 mins, making them almost impossible to finish. If this is the "quality education" SFU is talking about, I don't want it.

Memorize all 300+ pages of the textbook or fail. Quiz/Exam all based on memorization - down to the letter/graph/table on specific pages. Essays have very specific and unorganized rubrics, hard to get a good mark. Utterly disastrous and annoying professor. Terrible in every aspect, shouldn't be allowed to teach. Read the other reviews.

The incompetence of this professor is beyond what I believed was ever possible: the course material was littered with contraditions, and her emails reeked of unprofessionalism as they were full of typos. While the course went on, this litter spread like wildfire, and soon the entire course reeked of the rancid aroma radiating from her bad attitude.

Where do I even begin LOL. She's very disorganized and does not know how to test students well. For a technical writing course in computer science, we learned how to write as an engineer? The quizzes and midterms are completely mc and ask for random obscure sentences in the textbook. Essays are marked rather harshly; very few people get over 80%

This might be the most annoying course I've ever been in. It's like two courses in one, with essays and tests. Essays are marked by a specific rubric, and any small mistake results in a lost mark. Tests are done by memorizing the textbook. Don't know the example on pg 43? Guess that mark is gone now. Easy to get a B, almost impossible get an A.

Before this class, be sure to bring a pillow because you're gonna be falling asleep 2 min into lecture. Don't forget to bring a pillow for your pillow because your pillow is gonna fall asleep as well.

I'm not even sure where to start, this prof is far from fit to teach this course, let alone teach at all. She speeds through lecture content, which I doubt she understands herself. The rubrics for every assignment are utterly disorganized and information is always contradicting. She also expects you to memorize the entire textbook for exams.

Terrible Prof. She taught this class in 2 sections, and she gave a lot of information to one that she didn't to the other, we heard about it FROM those students in the previous class. She gave a crazy amount of quizzes in the beginning and her quizzes are the most random, precise sentences from a an engineering book. Not a good fit for this course!

Do I even need to explain why? Read the reviews in her Langara profile on this site. This class is useless. Nothing computer science related, all memorization and essays. She doesnt even have a PHD in CS. Avoid at all costs. Maybe shes different in person? Change my mind after Covid is gone.
